byline.original: By GARDINER HARRIS and ROBERT PEAR

abstract: News analysis; new health care law which would have given 50 dollars a day to help middle class families provide home care to disabled family members, and those suffering from dementia, dies quiet death in troubled political environment; law's failure leaves millions of such Americans to fend for their relatives themselves, an often crippling economic burden.
snippet: Many members of the middle class have to look after their disabled relatives themselves, or pay someone to do it.
lead_paragraph: Many members of the middle class have to look after their disabled relatives themselves, or pay someone to do it.

headline.main: Still No Relief in Sight for Long-Term Needs
headline.print_headline: Still No Relief in Sight For Long-Term Needs
headline.seo: With Class Act’s Failure, Still No Relief in Sight for Long-Term Care
